name: Ki (Qi) - Life Energy
shortDescription: The vital life energy or spiritual force that flows through all living things
fullDescription: Ki (Ê∞ó), known as Qi or Chi in Chinese, is the fundamental life energy or vital force that flows through all living things and the universe itself. In Japanese culture, ki is the animating essence that distinguishes living from non-living, the breath that gives life, and the spiritual energy that connects all beings. The concept was imported from Chinese philosophy (Daoism, traditional medicine) but integrated deeply into Japanese martial arts, healing practices, and spiritual traditions. Ki flows through the body via meridians, and health depends on its balanced circulation. Martial artists cultivate and direct ki for power and technique (as in Aikido, 'the way of harmonizing ki'). Healers work to restore disrupted ki flow. The concept relates to, but is distinct from, kami‚Äîwhile kami are discrete spiritual beings, ki is the universal energy they embody and channel. Many Japanese words incorporate ki: genki (healthy, literally 'original ki'), kimochi (feeling, 'ki-ÊåÅ„Å°'), kokoro (heart/mind, containing ki character), tenki (weather, 'heaven-ki').

manifestations.description: Ki manifests as: breath and breathing (kokyu), vitality and health (genki), emotional states (kimochi), focused intent in martial arts, healing energy in traditional medicine, the seasonal flow of nature (shiki - four seasons), atmospheric conditions (tenki - weather), and the living presence felt in sacred spaces. Practitioners can cultivate, direct, and sense ki through meditation, breathing exercises, and martial training.

originPoint.name: Imported from China, integrated into Japanese thought
originPoint.description: Ki concept entered Japan from China during Asuka period (538-710 CE) through Buddhist and Daoist texts, centered in Nara/Kyoto cultural zone. Merged with native concepts of tama (soul) and musubi (creative power).

firstAttestation.description: Ki appears in early Japanese Buddhist texts and medical writings from Asuka period, borrowed from Chinese sources.

timelinePosition.description: Ki concept imported during Asuka period (538-710 CE) through Chinese Buddhist and Daoist texts, integrated into Japanese martial arts, medicine, and philosophy during Heian period and beyond.
